channel.title: The Day in Mets History
channel.itunes:author: WonderAI
channel.description:
Step into the world of Mets baseball history with this meticulously crafted daily podcast that unearths compelling stories from the team's rich past. Each 5-7 minute episode transports listeners to a specific date in Mets history, combining masterful storytelling with lesser-known details that even die-hard fans might have missed. From dramatic game-winning moments to behind-the-scenes decisions that shaped the franchise, every episode delivers a slice of Mets heritage with the warmth and authenticity of a conversation at your favorite baseball bar.
The show's deliberate pacing and vintage newspaper-style narration creates an intimate atmosphere that celebrates both milestone moments and overlooked gems. Whether it's reliving a classic game, exploring an impactful trade, or uncovering a quirky footnote in team history, each episode weaves together carefully researched facts with compelling narrative to paint a complete picture of what makes each date special in Mets lore.
Disclaimer: This description is experimental and was generated by AI. It may contain factual errors.
channel.itunes:summary: Daily podcast explores significant dates in Mets history through intimate storytelling and lesser known facts.

itunes:category.text: Sports > Baseball, Sports > History, Arts > Storytelling

item.title: June 22: When Seaver Said Goodbye and Washington Shined
item.itunes:title: June 22: When Seaver Said Goodbye and Washington Shined
item.description:
June 22 stands as a pivotal date in New York Mets history, marked by both triumph and farewell. In 1969, Jerry Koosman led the emerging Miracle Mets to a crucial 5-1 victory over the defending National League champion Cardinals at Shea Stadium before 50,000 faithful fans. Exactly eighteen years later, the franchise faced a poignant moment when Tom Seaver, the greatest Met of all time, announced his retirement on June 22, 1987. After 20 remarkable seasons, 311 wins, and three Cy Young Awards, "Tom Terrific" concluded his legendary career where it began. The date also witnessed Claudell Washington's extraordinary performance in 1977, when he blasted three home runs at Dodger Stadium in a 9-6 Mets victory, demonstrating baseball's capacity for unexpected brilliance even in challenging seasons.
Learn More: • 'Tom Seaver: The Franchise' (https://wondery.com/shows/baseball-stories) • 'The Miracle Mets: The Story of the 1969 New York Mets - Book' (https://amazon.com/dp/1613217544) • 'Baseball's Greatest Games: 1969 World Series Game 5 - Documentary' (https://primevideo.com/baseball-greatest-games) • 'Tom Seaver's Hall of Fame Career' (https://baseballhall.org/hall-of-famers/seaver-tom)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Mets history: Koosman's 1969 win, Seaver's retirement in 1987, Washington's three-homer game on June 22.

item.title: Seven Solo Shots: The Night the Mets Found Their Groove
item.itunes:title: Seven Solo Shots: The Night the Mets Found Their Groove
item.description:
Seven solo home runs illuminated Citizens Bank Park as the New York Mets snapped their seven-game losing streak with an emphatic 11-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The power display reached its peak in an electrifying third inning when Francisco Lindor, Brandon Nimmo, and Juan Soto launched back-to-back-to-back home runs, sending shockwaves through the baseball world. Nimmo and Soto each contributed two home runs to the historic performance, while Jared Young and Francisco Alvarez added to the barrage with solo shots of their own. The game marked a significant milestone for Juan Soto, who achieved his 27th multi-homer game before turning 27, placing him among baseball's elite power hitters. This remarkable display of offensive firepower not only ended the Mets' losing streak but potentially signaled a turning point in their 2025 season, reminiscent of the 2016 season when seven solo home runs were last witnessed in a major league game. As "New York Groove" echoed through the visitors' clubhouse, the victory stood as more than just a regular-season win—it became an instant classic in Mets history, combining individual achievement with team resurgence.
Learn More: • MLB Game Recap (https://www.reuters.com/sports/mlb-roundup-mets-hit-7-hrs-vs-phils-halt-7-game-skid-2025-06-22/) • Complete Game Statistics (https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI202506220.shtml) • Mets-Phillies Rivalry History (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mets-Phillies_rivalry) • Citizens Bank Park Guide (https://www.mlb.com/phillies/ballpark)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Mets crush Phillies with 7 home runs, Soto leads historic 11-4 victory ending 7-game losing streak

item.title: June 25th: When Lightning Strikes Twice at Citi Field
item.itunes:title: June 25th: When Lightning Strikes Twice at Citi Field
item.description:
Baseball history intertwines magnificently as Juan Soto blasts two home runs at Citi Field, echoing the magic of past June 25th heroics in Mets history. Soto's powerful display, marking his 27th career multi-homer game and surpassing Hall of Famer Jimmie Foxx for most such games before age 27, parallels Mike Phillips' unforgettable cycle at Wrigley Field in 1976. The date holds special significance in Mets lore, from Phillips breaking his 0-for-21 slump in spectacular fashion to the rare 1989 feat where the Mets recorded zero defensive assists in their victory over Philadelphia. Soto's performance, including a decisive 413-foot blast to center field that sparked a five-run fourth inning, adds another chapter to this storied date. His remarkable night, featuring two solo home runs in a crucial 7-3 victory over the Braves, showcases how baseball's past and present converge in moments of brilliance.
Learn More: • 'This Week in Baseball History' (https://wondery.com/shows/this-week-in-baseball-history) • 'Baseball's Greatest Games' (https://wondery.com/shows/baseballs-greatest-games) • 'The New York Mets: A Complete Illustrated History - Book' (https://amazon.com/dp/1600783910) • 'Mets by the Numbers' (https://metsbythenumbers.com/date/6-25) • 'Juan Soto Player Profile' (https://www.mlb.com/player/juan-soto-665742)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
item.itunes:summary: Juan Soto hits two home runs, breaks records at Citi Field in Mets historic 7-3 Braves victory

item.title: Seaver's Dance with Perfection: The Lost Gem of '69
item.itunes:title: Seaver's Dance with Perfection: The Lost Gem of '69
item.description:
Tom Seaver's masterful pitching performance on a sweltering 90-degree afternoon at Shea Stadium in 1969 stands as one of baseball's most memorable near-perfect games. For eight and one-third innings, Seaver dominated the Philadelphia Phillies, retiring the first 25 batters in order as the tension mounted with each passing frame. The Mets' ace, supported by Tommie Agee's solo home run, carried a perfect game into the ninth inning before Jimmy Qualls delivered a clean single to left-center field with one out. Despite losing the perfect game, Seaver completed a brilliant shutout with 10 strikeouts in the Mets' 4-0 victory. The same date in 1964 witnessed another historic moment at Shea Stadium when the Mets and Phillies engaged in an epic 23-inning marathon that remains the longest complete game in Mets history. The seven-hour, twenty-three-minute contest featured 17 pitchers throwing a staggering 658 pitches, with the Phillies finally prevailing in the 23rd inning.
Learn More: • "Tom Seaver Nearly Perfect" (https://baseballhall.org/discover/inside-pitch/tom-seaver-nearly-perfect) • "The Day in Baseball History" (https://thisdayinbaseball.com/tom-seavers-near-perfect-game-immortalized-as-the-imperfect-game/) • "Longest Games in Mets History" (https://www.amazinavenue.com/2015/7/23/9026111/new-york-mets-longest-games-history) • "Tom Seaver's Near-Perfect Game" - Documentary (https://www.mlb.com/mets/video/seaver-s-near-perfect-game-c3531274)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.
